title: "We can't nerf Lee Sin because of community backlash"
body:
Meanwhile consecutive Sona nerfs and even a rework despite community backlash.

Yup.

replies.body:
Riot: "Sona's dealing too much damage for a support."

Lee Sin mains: "If I play support I bet I can steal all the kills with my Q."

>
> Riot: "Sona's dealing too much damage for a support."
> 
> Lee Sin mains: "If I play support I bet I can steal all the kills with my Q."

At this point, Lee Sin support works better than Sona.

Harass - check
CC- check
Shield - check
Builds sightstone - check (probably for selfish reasons BUT HEY, it's a ward - more than you're going to get from "support" Nidalee)

My roommate was able to play Lee Sin support completely smashed last week and he still managed to do good. Hell, with him in the bottom lane we were able to assert an absolutely insane amount of dragon control. Starting after we were both level 3 we got five consecutive dragons in a row.

I'd go so far as to argue that if someone who doesn't even play Lee Sin can be completely wasted and have absolutely no issue not only playing him outside of his role, but playing him *effectively* as he's normally played all the same, Lee Sin isn't half as hard as most would lead you to believe.

Sorry, but Q Flash E E R Q isn't hard. And that's usually more than enough to finish someone off who's also taking damage from an ally.

Thank you for finally saying it. It's not at all hard to execute his combos. He has a low skill floor just like Zed because anyone can pick him up and learn his combos quickly and do alright if not well. He does however have a high skill CAP just like Zed because a true Lee Sin main will come up with unique ways of hopping about just like a Zed main would find new ways to trick people, kill them and get away.

A champ with a high skill floor would be someone like Azir or Yasuo where positioning is key and any mistep will land you in trouble because they're both squishy. They have methods of protection (Wind wall and Emperor's Divide) but they are both on very long cooldowns.

> [{quoted}](name=Brenticus12,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=uYUE15Aj,comment-id=0000000000000000,timestamp=2015-01-06T12:34:52.879+0000)

> 
> A champ with a high skill floor would be someone like Azir or Yasuo where positioning is key and any mistep will land you in trouble because they're both squishy. They have methods of protection (Wind wall and Emperor's Divide) but they are both on very long cooldowns.

Azir? Sure. Form a solid defensive line and stay behind it, no one can get to you. Try and do the attacking yourself, you're gonna get your face bashed back into the sands.

Yasuo? Just a ranged Yi so far as I'm concerned. Between Wind Wall and his full flow shield he's TOO forgiving on his positioning. He's even allowed to safely ult into the middle of a teamfight because his ult gives him a free shield once again even if he has 0 flow when using it. You know how many other champions can dive into the enemy team and completely mitigate the next source of damage that's going to come at them while being able to dash away and block any following projectiles?

None.

Until Nocturne gets a free spellshield when he uses his ult, until Vi's shield can drastically increase the damage it can absorb, until Jarvan can reinforce his shield from ulting the enemy team, Yasuo is being given too much for too little given how much damage is in the rest of his kit. No one should have that much mobility, range, armor shred, damage, and damage mitigation all in one kit for free.

Q Q Q R is not a hard combo but it's all he needs to win teamfights.

There's on major thing you overlooked regarding Yasuo's ult and as someone who plays him I feel the need to correct you:
Yasuo's ult has something that only one other uses, **his ult requires setup**. You either must have landed two of your Qs on nearby enemy minions, or an enemy champion to use his knockup to allow the ult, or have a fellow champion charge in for you. Unlike both Nocturne and Vi, you don't just point and click and it happens, but you must either land your Q or have someone else send them up.

P.S. Every tried to ult Lucian as Yasuo? It's friken impossible.

> [{quoted}](name=Sypher40,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=uYUE15Aj,comment-id=000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2015-01-06T20:17:52.739+0000)

> 
> P.S. Every tried to ult Lucian as Yasuo? It's friken impossible.

Because pressing Q three times is hard to do on a low cooldown skill with high range for the final Q and a wide hitbox. In most cases I'd go so far as to say a bullshit hitbox considering I've been caught in the tornado with more than a Teemo between the edge of the tornado and I. That isn't very hard to set up, especially given how low the cooldown on his Q is.

Ever tried to ult Yasuo as Lucian? He shoves his dick through the Wind Wall just to taunt at you behind it.

I'm sorry, but I don't care what anyone has to say, or how weak he becomes if he DOES get caught in some CC. He's getting too much for too little.

Quick list of Yasuo stuff:
Q has a max cooldown if 1.33 seconds.
The hitbox for the tornado may be large, but it's really slow.
His dodge relies on enemies and neutrals, and can only be used once on them before a 6 second cooldown.
Windwall's CD ranges from 22-18 seconds. Long either way.
His early game is crap. I normally don't even build damage until my third item.

> [{quoted}](name=Sypher40,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=uYUE15Aj,comment-id=00000000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2015-01-06T21:07:08.403+0000)
>
> Quick list of Yasuo stuff:
> Q has a max cooldown if 1.33 seconds.

That's still low for the amount of poke it does and how quickly it allows him to get stacks on the Q to send out the only set up he needs to rip a team apart.

> The hitbox for the tornado may be large, but it's really slow.

I'd call it undefined before I'd call it just large. I've been hit by tornadoes that had no place affecting me while passing right over other champs directly in it's path. I'd honestly believe that it's got some bugs that need to be worked out. 

> His dodge relies on enemies and neutrals, and can only be used once on them before a 6 second cooldown.

He only needs to be able to do it once to juke a skillshot that might be the only immediately available method of CCing him.

> Windwall's CD ranges from 22-18 seconds. Long either way.

Doesn't matter how long the cooldown is when he only needs to use it once to make a clean getaway.

> His early game is crap. I normally don't even build damage until my third item.

Every Yasuo who gets first blood at level 1 or level 2 disagrees.

If Yasuo is getting first blood at level 1 or 2 then he's matched up against a moron. Talk to anyone who actually plays him, and they well tell you his early game is awful. All my runes and masteries for him are just for surviving until I get Infinity Edge.

Um, no, not at all. Any small mistakes he makes will be severely punished. If he gets neutered early game he can't get back unless the game ends with everyone at full build. 

Thing is, Yasuo can only dash through enemies so he has to be aggressive to be useful. Being aggressive means getting targetted by CC and he is a sustained fighter meaning he needs to stick to targets. Yes, a fed Yasuo is a complete terror just like any duelist fighter or assassin but that's why you abuse the fact that his early game is shit.  He has no other forms of protection other than his wind wall and his shield because he is probably the squishiest fighter there is. 

Do you know why Yasuo gets a free shield on ult? Because mid-late it doesn't even matter anymore cause that shiekd will trigger and dissipitate faster than you can land after you finish your ult. The shield has been nerfed numerous times, it's not as big as when SKT Wolf killed the entire enemy team.at the Nexus with a sliver of health left.

Nocturne is normally a bruiser meaning he is tanky. Vi is also very tanky. Jarvan is also another tanky bruiser. They are all extremely tanky bruisers and can take a beating but unless Yasuo is fed and rushed BT while the enemies don't have their own core items yet, then he has no means of surviving other than to hope that he doesn't die instantly during and after ult.

And I'd like to see you do a 3-5 man Yasuo QQQR Combo in any Elo above Silver. It is not as easy as you think.

Even fucking Yi has damage mitigation and sustain in the form of his W. Trynd has it in his Q and ult. I could keep going on.

You can learn his combos just like you can learn Azir's combos but it doesn't change the fact that it is very difficult and tedious to execute them unless you were extremely fed early in which case any champion is easy to play as.

> [{quoted}](name=Brenticus12,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=uYUE15Aj,comment-id=000000000000000000000001,timestamp=2015-01-06T20:19:18.047+0000)
>
> Um, no, not at all. Any small mistakes he makes will be severely punished. If he gets neutered early game he can't get back unless the game ends with everyone at full build. 

Except that he can just QQQR for a teamfight in the early game then dash back out with up two two shiels and a godmodded wind wall to protect him while his team finishes the job he started off of just his ult. He doesn't have to contribute after that beyond hanging back and poking, and can very easily get fed off of assists to regain his power during the mid game going into late.

> 
> Thing is, Yasuo can only dash through enemies so he has to be aggressive to be useful. Being aggressive means getting targetted by CC and he is a sustained fighter meaning he needs to stick to targets. Yes, a fed Yasuo is a complete terror just like any duelist fighter or assassin but that's why you abuse the fact that his early game is shit.  He has no other forms of protection other than his wind wall and his shield because he is probably the squishiest fighter there is. 

Yes, so give the guy who has to be aggressive to be useful up to three methods of damage mitigation or completely stopping it, give his sustained damage so much burst that he doesn't have to deal it for more than a second or two, and give him the ability to provide two different CC effects as well. And make it so that he only needs two items to crit every single time he right clicks or Qs someone when ADCs, who's kits revolve around the same concept, have to build three items to guarantee critical strikes and give up on damage to build that third crit chance item when he can just keep right on trucking on damage items.

> 
> Do you know why Yasuo gets a free shield on ult? Because mid-late it doesn't even matter anymore cause that shiekd will trigger and dissipitate faster than you can land after you finish your ult. The shield has been nerfed numerous times, it's not as big as when SKT Wolf killed the entire enemy team.at the Nexus with a sliver of health left.

Except it isn't hard to QQQR, then use the shield to buy you have a second as you E/Flash away to get some distance, then block whatever's flying at you with Wind Wall so you make a completely free escape.

> 
> Nocturne is normally a bruiser meaning he is tanky. Vi is also very tanky. Jarvan is also another tanky bruiser. They are all extremely tanky bruisers and can take a beating but unless Yasuo is fed and rushed BT while the enemies don't have their own core items yet, then he has no means of surviving other than to hope that he doesn't die instantly during and after ult.

Nocturne isn't normally a bruiser, he's normally either a high damage assassin or a fighter. He only builds bruiser if he's falling behind. Vi is tanky, but she isn't getting as much free damage mitigation for diving someone as Yasuo has access too, even with her passive shield. She isn't blocking the next damaging ability or negating the next several that come at her. Jarvan isn't either. Building tanky is what allows them to survive the engagement, but it's stacked in Yasuo's favor when he can build more damage and mitigate so much that he doesn't even take any on his way back out before his team crashes down on you.

> 
> And I'd like to see you do a 3-5 man Yasuo QQQR Combo in any Elo above Silver. It is not as easy as you think.

It's much more about where the enemies are than where you are. Late game that's not hard if they group up... which is the standard late game strategy.

> 
> Even fucking Yi has damage mitigation and sustain in the form of his W. Trynd has it in his Q and ult. I could keep going on.

Yi is reducing the damage dealt, not completely cancelling it. Trynd risks dying the moment his ult ends, and it's easy to make him waste it.

> 
> You can learn his combos just like you can learn Azir's combos but it doesn't change the fact that it is very difficult and tedious to execute them unless you were extremely fed early in which case any champion is easy to play as.

E four times through a minion wave then E through the enemy laner to deal maximum harass damage. Do so with full flow and it's free harass on them. Q twice on minions and then send a third Q at the enemy laner to poke them. Please excuse me while I get try to process how insanely difficult it is to press the same button multiple times. Azir's combos require careful positioning of both his soldiers and himself. Yasuo's combos require something with a red health bar to be somewhere nearby. They aren't the same, and unlike Yasuo, with Azir you get punished by losing your ability to escape or mitigate damage with his shield if you make a bad positioning choice. Yasuo can get caught out and still get away between his high mobility and two different ways of negating damage from chasing enemies.
